Award.AwardTitle: NeTS: Large: Collaborative Research:Programmable Inter-domain Observation and Control

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Internet is an essential part of modern society, playing a vital role in a wide range of educational, commercial, military, and social activities. However, network operators today have a limited ability to observe and control the paths used to carry traffic across the Internet. For example, although it is often beneficial for several networks to cooperate?e.g., a content provider and cellular network jointly picking the best paths from content to customers?existing Internet routing protocols make it difficult to share information or collaborate to select routes. These limitations contribute to a host of problems, including decreased path stability, degraded performance, and service outages.

This project will develop a system called IN-CONTROL that aggregates information from participating networks and active measurements into an inter-domain network information base (iNIB). The iNIB presents operators with a unified interface for making observations about global forwarding paths and a rich control interface for issuing requests to steer traffic along preferred paths. To build the iNIB, the project is focusing on the following tasks: (i) developing provenance-based techniques to obtain reliable results from computations performed over potentially-untrustworthy data (ii) designing deployable mechanisms for observing and controlling Internet forwarding paths, and (iii) building a scalable implementation that incorporates optimizations to reduce resource demands for answering iNIB queries. The intellectual merit of this research lies in developing reliable abstractions for observing and controlling Internet forwarding paths and a scalable implementation that can be readily deployed on the current Internet.

The broader impacts include reducing the fragility of the Internet, and broadening the interdisciplinary community of researchers working on problems related to inter-domain networking. This project also provides research experiences for undergraduate students and members of under-represented groups.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project developed platforms for improving the performance and reliability of large enterprise networks and the Internet.  The operation of these networks is founded on collecting observations of network behavior, which are used to control traffic delivery. The project resulted in four sets of outcomes for improved observation and control in enterprise networks (“intradomain”) and the Internet (“interdomain”).

The first set of outcomes has resulted in improved observation and control in software-defined enterprise networks. We introduced probabilistic in-band network telemetry to collect information (such as switch hops, queue length, latency) with limited overhead and high accuracy. We also developed Lyra, a new language and compiler for programming application-specific integrated circuit (ASIC) based switches that permit advanced load balancing, flowlet switching, and in-network caches. 

The second set of outcomes developed techniques for control over interdomain routing. Whereas software-defined networking has seen dramatic adoption in enterprise and data center networks, where a network is a single administrative domain under unified control, there had been negligible uptake in the interdomain setting. The key challenge in that setting is that the domains have to interoperate, and there are tens of thousands of domains with millions of devices limited to legacy protocols, creating essentially insurmountable barriers to adopting new approaches unless they are completely backwards compatible. The domains must interconnect using the Border Gateway Protocol (BGP), which enables global Internet reachability but (a) provides only limited, indirect ways of expressing desired routing policies, (b) enacts control decisions at the router, without a flexible way to delegate control to multiple upstream entities, and (c) is agnostic to important criteria such as performance, reliability, capacity, and demand, leading to suboptimal routing. We addressed these problems by decoupling control from routers to enable greater flexibility. First, we introduced a scheme that separates routing policies from route dissemination, allowing centralized negotiation, richer policy expression, and win-win outcomes for multiple domains. Second, we developed backwards-compatible techniques to virtualize control of a router, enabling multiple entities to simultaneously have visibility and control equivalent to if they had dedicated direct access to it. These techniques form the basis for the PEERING testbed, which enables experiments that exchange routes and traffic with a thousand real domains in locations around the world. Third, we adapted the technique to deploy in a system called Edge Fabric, developed in collaboration with Facebook, that routes Facebook traffic to its users around the world. Edge Fabric observes performance, capacity, and demand, then overrides the decisions of routers when they make suboptimal decisions. Edge Fabric has influenced the architecture of other companies including Microsoft and Akamai.   

A third set of outcomes focuses on architecting wide-area networks, both at the network level and at the router-level, for performance and reliability. Our measurements have shown that direct connectivity between end-user facing ISPs and large content providers like Google and Facebook has resulted in a noticeable flattening of the Internet (as compared to its traditional hierarchical network-level topology). To enable direct connectivity, content providers roll out their own wide-area networks. Our measurements demonstrated that this strategy has mixed benefits, and improves performance for about half the users compared to using the public Internet. Finally, these wide-area networks use sophisticated routers susceptible to internal failures; we have shown how to mask these failures using carefully designed routing strategies.

The final set of outcomes explores the control of content delivery. To improve user-perceived performance, video delivery systems adapt to changes in the network by adapting the quality of the delivered video. Our work on Oboe showed how to improve this adaptation by explicitly detecting changes in network state. With Microsoft, we deployed a system Odin that monitors performance and availability for Microsoft users worldwide. Odin measurements enable fast identification of outages and are the basis for performance optimizations that benefit users of Microsoft services. With Akamai, we developed techniques to determine the optimal subset of web content to push to clients to reduce the time to load web pages. Finally, to prevent malicious traffic to content networks, we developed a system that evaluates and aggregates multiple blacklists feeds, producing a more useful, accurate and timely master blacklist.  

The project resulted in several publications and solutions deployed in industry. The grant helped train: 3 post-doctoral scholars (two of whom are now faculty, including one at UC Santa Barbara); 1 PhD student who is now a lead research scientist and Assistant Professor at the U.S. Military Academy and 5 PhD students who have since joined Google, Verizon, Microsoft and Amazon; 8 PhD students who are currently enrolled in the PhD program; 4 masters students, 1 currently applying to PhD programs and the others working at Google, Thousand Eyes, and Two Sigma; and several undergrads, some preparing to apply to PhD programs.
